qas.question: What aspect of historical styles did a lot of architects find lacking in modernist styles?
Who were three architects who influenced Brutalism?

answers.text: Paul Rudolph, Marcel Breuer, and Eero Saarinen

qas.question: What material was used in Brutalist structures?
Who disagreed with the aesthetic of Brutalism?
What aspect of historical styles did a lot of architects find booming in modernist styles?

plausible_answers.text: Paul Rudolph, Marcel Breuer, and Eero Saarinen

qas.question: Who were three architects who discouraged Brutalism?
What material was never used in Brutalist structures?
Who agreed with the aesthetic of Brutalism?

context: Many architects resisted modernism, finding it devoid of the <a0_0><b4_0>decorative richness<b4_0/><a0_0/> of historical styles. As the first generation of modernists began to die after WWII, a second generation of architects including <a1_0><b5_0>Paul Rudolph, Marcel Breuer, and Eero Saarinen<b5_0/><a1_0/> tried to expand the aesthetics of modernism with Brutalism, buildings with expressive sculptural facades made of <a2_0><b6_0>unfinished concrete<b6_0/><a2_0/>. But an even new younger <a3_0><b7_0>postwar generation<b7_0/><a3_0/> critiqued modernism and Brutalism for being too austere, standardized, monotone, and not taking into account the richness of human experience offered in historical buildings across time and in different places and cultures.
